    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Excuse me, miss, but I'm sure someone else would be happy to take these off my hands at a fair price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
      Della Plumstone -- "How about four coins for the whole lot? That's a fair price, wouldn't you say?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, four coins it is.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins, and they're the finest fruit in Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he discovered a wilted daisy in the meadow behind his house. Instead of discarding it, he carefully arranged it in a small clay pot, adding a few pebbles and a drop of water from his mother's watering can. He proudly presented his creation to his mother, who was delighted by his ingenuity and imagination.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he accompanied his father to the local market. He was mesmerized by the vibrant colors and exotic smells of the fruits on display. Cedric, captivated by a particularly plump peach, struck up a conversation with the vendor, learning about the different varieties and their origins. He returned home that day with a newfound passion for the world of fruits.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced his father to let him set up a small stall at the village fair. He spent weeks collecting unusual fruits and vegetables from the surrounding countryside, arranging them in an eye-catching display. His stall, named "Cedric's Curiosities," was a huge success, and he learned the joy of sharing his passion with others.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he decided to travel to a neighboring village to sell his wares. He meticulously packed his cart with the finest fruits and vegetables, carefully selecting each item for its quality and appearance. His journey was a revelation, exposing him to new cultures and customs, and solidifying his desire to see the world.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a traveling merchant selling exotic spices. Inspired by the merchant's tales of faraway lands, Cedric decided to expand his business. He began to source unique fruits and vegetables from different regions, adding a touch of exoticism to his collection.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased his first horse-drawn cart, marking a significant step in his entrepreneurial journey. He named the cart "The Wandering Orchard," and it became his mobile showcase, allowing him to reach a wider audience and share his passion for fruits with the world.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a group of children who were marveling at his display of colorful fruits. He spent the afternoon sharing stories and legends about each fruit, captivating their imaginations and inspiring a love for nature's bounty in their hearts.

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins, and they're the finest fruit in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins, or he could try to negotiate a higher price.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is negotiating the price with Della Plumstone.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.




          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins, or he could try to negotiate a higher price.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting four coins is 6, because he believes the fruit is worth five coins and feels the pain of losing one coin acutely, and the loss of rejecting the offer and trying to negotiate is 10, because he risks losing the entire sale and gaining nothing if Della walks away.




          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he discovered a wilted daisy in the meadow behind his house. Instead of discarding it, he carefully arranged it in a small clay pot, adding a few pebbles and a drop of water from his mother's watering can. He proudly presented his creation to his mother, who was delighted by his ingenuity and imagination.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he accompanied his father to the local market. He was mesmerized by the vibrant colors and exotic smells of the fruits on display. Cedric, captivated by a particularly plump peach, struck up a conversation with the vendor, learning about the different varieties and their origins. He returned home that day with a newfound passion for the world of fruits.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced his father to let him set up a small stall at the village fair. He spent weeks collecting unusual fruits and vegetables from the surrounding countryside, arranging them in an eye-catching display. His stall, named "Cedric's Curiosities," was a huge success, and he learned the joy of sharing his passion with others.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he decided to travel to a neighboring village to sell his wares. He meticulously packed his cart with the finest fruits and vegetables, carefully selecting each item for its quality and appearance. His journey was a revelation, exposing him to new cultures and customs, and solidifying his desire to see the world.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a traveling merchant selling exotic spices. Inspired by the merchant's tales of faraway lands, Cedric decided to expand his business. He began to source unique fruits and vegetables from different regions, adding a touch of exoticism to his collection.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased his first horse-drawn cart, marking a significant step in his entrepreneurial journey. He named the cart "The Wandering Orchard," and it became his mobile showcase, allowing him to reach a wider audience and share his passion for fruits with the world.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a group of children who were marveling at his display of colorful fruits. He spent the afternoon sharing stories and legends about each fruit, captivating their imaginations and inspiring a love for nature's bounty in their hearts.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins, or he could try to negotiate a higher price.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting four coins is 6, because he believes the fruit is worth five coins and feels the pain of losing one coin acutely, and the loss of rejecting the offer and trying to negotiate is 10, because he risks losing the entire sale and gaining nothing if Della walks away.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Recalled memories and observations:
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion :
          Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer:
          Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins, or he could try to negotiate a higher price.


          The current time: 1895-09-13 00:05:00

          The characteristics of the current scenario in game theory perspective: The current scenario is a classic example of a bargaining or negotiation game in game theory.





          Reflection on the previous options: From a loss aversion perspective, Cedric is likely to resist Della's offer of four coins. He has a history of driving a hard bargain and aiming for the highest possible profit, suggesting a tendency to feel the pain of a loss more acutely than the pleasure of an equivalent gain. Accepting four coins would represent a loss of potential profit, which he may be unwilling to concede.

          From a game theory perspective, Cedric faces a dilemma. Accepting four coins guarantees a small but certain profit (3 coins). Rejecting the offer and attempting to negotiate a higher price risks walking away with nothing if Della doesn't budge. Cedric's previous actions, however, indicate he's willing to take risks to maximize his gains. He might try to push for a price closer to his desired five coins, hoping to exploit Della's apparent willingness to pay. This strategy, however, carries the risk of losing the entire transaction if Della walks away.





          Reflection on other people's previous actions: From a game theory perspective, both Cedric and Della are trying to maximize their payoff in this negotiation. Cedric wants to sell his fruit for the highest price possible (to maximize his profit), while Della wants to buy the fruit at the lowest price possible (to minimize her cost).

          Cedric's initial offer of five coins suggests he believes the fruit is worth that much and is willing to start the negotiation at a higher price. Della's counteroffer of four coins indicates she believes the fruit is worth less and is trying to leverage Cedric into accepting a lower price.

          Their past interactions and the general market conditions (the average price of fruit being three coins) provide context for their current actions. Cedric's history of driving a hard bargain suggests he's not easily swayed and might be willing to hold out for a higher price. Della's previous successful negotiation with Lennon Figtree shows she's adept at bargaining and willing to walk away if the price isn't right.




          Options available to Cedric Meadowbrook: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins, or he could try to negotiate a higher price.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting four coins is 6, because he believes the fruit is worth five coins and feels the pain of losing one coin acutely, and the loss of rejecting the offer and trying to negotiate is 10, because he risks losing the entire sale and gaining nothing if Della walks away.

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins, and they're the finest fruit in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.

1895-09-13 00:05:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Excuse me, miss, but I'm sure someone else would be happy to take these off my hands at a fair price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
      Della Plumstone -- "How about four coins for the whole lot? That's a fair price, wouldn't you say?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, four coins it is.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins, and they're the finest fruit in Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
    Active player

      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone can continue to negotiate with Cedric Meadowbrook for a lower price or she can move on to another merchant.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she decided to strike out on her own, setting up her own fruit stall at the market. She saved diligently, buying and selling fruit from her father's farm, carefully cultivating her reputation for honesty and fair dealing.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she traveled to a distant village, seeking out a rare and exotic fruit. She encountered a shrewd merchant who tried to overcharge her, but Della, using her wit and charm, managed to secure the fruit at a fair price.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Excuse me, miss, but I'm sure someone else would be happy to take these off my hands at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about four coins for the whole lot? That's a fair price, wouldn't you say?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, four coins it is.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.

          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she accompanied her father to the bustling city marketplace. Overwhelmed by the crowds and the cacophony of noise, she felt a surge of panic. Her father, sensing her distress, took her hand and guided her through the maze of stalls, teaching her the art of bartering and negotiation. As she successfully haggled for a rare variety of pears, Della felt a sense of accomplishment and confidence bloom within her.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she overheard two men arguing over the price of a crate of oranges. One man, a gruff merchant, was trying to cheat the other, a young farmer. Della, her voice surprisingly firm, stepped in and, using her knowledge of the market, exposed the merchant's deception. The farmer, grateful for her intervention, offered her a share of his profits.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she decided to strike out on her own, setting up her own fruit stall at the market. She saved diligently, buying and selling fruit from her father's farm, carefully cultivating her reputation for honesty and fair dealing.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins, and they're the finest fruit in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Della Plumstone is a shrewd merchant who successfully bartered for goods on two separate occasions in the bustling market of Fruitville.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.




          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can continue to negotiate with Cedric Meadowbrook for a lower price or she can move on to another merchant.


          Question: Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to continue negotiating with Cedric Meadowbrook for a lower price.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 3 coins
    Active player

      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 3 coins

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Excuse me, miss, but I'm sure someone else would be happy to take these off my hands at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, four coins it is.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about four coins for the whole lot? That's a fair price, wouldn't you say?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins, and they're the finest fruit in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who successfully negotiated a deal the previous day and is currently attempting to bargain for fruit in Fruitville. She is known for her ability to find a price that suits both parties.

It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can offer Cedric Meadowbrook three coins and a half for the fruit.

          Question: Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to offer three coins and a half for the fruit.

        • 1895-09-13 00:10:00

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept

  • Cedric Meadowbrook

    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he decided to travel to a neighboring village to sell his wares. He meticulously packed his cart with the finest fruits and vegetables, carefully selecting each item for its quality and appearance. His journey was a revelation, exposing him to new cultures and customs, and solidifying his desire to see the world.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a traveling merchant selling exotic spices. Inspired by the merchant's tales of faraway lands, Cedric decided to expand his business. He began to source unique fruits and vegetables from different regions, adding a touch of exoticism to his collection.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased his first horse-drawn cart, marking a significant step in his entrepreneurial journey. He named the cart "The Wandering Orchard," and it became his mobile showcase, allowing him to reach a wider audience and share his passion for fruits with the world.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a group of children who were marveling at his display of colorful fruits. He spent the afternoon sharing stories and legends about each fruit, captivating their imaginations and inspiring a love for nature's bounty in their hearts.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Excuse me, miss, but I'm sure someone else would be happy to take these off my hands at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about four coins for the whole lot? That's a fair price, wouldn't you say?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, four coins it is.

He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of three and a half coins or reject it.

        • 1895-09-13 00:10:00

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have.           Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone, and they are currently negotiating the price.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of three and a half coins or reject it.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer is 6, because he would be losing half a coin compared to what he initially agreed upon, and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 8, because he risks losing the entire sale and having to find another buyer.




          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.




          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)
        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone, and they are currently negotiating the price.




          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of three and a half coins or reject it.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer is 6, because he would be losing half a coin compared to what he initially agreed upon, and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 8, because he risks losing the entire sale and having to find another buyer.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.



          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:10:00

        • Recent memories of Cedric Meadowbrook:

His journey was a revelation, exposing him to new cultures and customs, and solidifying his desire to see the world.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a traveling merchant selling exotic spices. Inspired by the merchant's tales of faraway lands, Cedric decided to expand his business. He began to source unique fruits and vegetables from different regions, adding a touch of exoticism to his collection.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased his first horse-drawn cart, marking a significant step in his entrepreneurial journey. He named the cart "The Wandering Orchard," and it became his mobile showcase, allowing him to reach a wider audience and share his passion for fruits with the world.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a group of children who were marveling at his display of colorful fruits. He spent the afternoon sharing stories and legends about each fruit, captivating their imaginations and inspiring a love for nature's bounty in their hearts.

          [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone, and they are currently negotiating the price.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Recalled memories and observations:
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?


          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion :
          Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer:
          Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of three and a half coins or reject it.


          The current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00

          The characteristics of the current scenario in game theory perspective: The current scenario presents a classic example of a bargaining game, a type of negotiation where two parties with differing valuations attempt to reach an agreement.




          Reflection on the previous options: From a loss aversion perspective, Cedric Meadowbrook is likely to be more sensitive to the potential loss of half a coin than the potential gain of negotiating a higher price. He has already agreed to four coins, so accepting three and a half feels like a concession and a loss. Game theory suggests that Cedric should consider Della Plumstone's likely response to his decision. If he rejects the offer, there's a chance Della Plumstone walks away, leaving Cedric with no sale. However, if he accepts, he secures a smaller profit but avoids the risk of losing the sale altogether.




          Reflection on other people's previous actions: Della Plumstone's actions suggest a strategy of gradual concession. She initially offered a price lower than Cedric Meadowbrook's asking price, demonstrating her willingness to negotiate. After Cedric accepted her first offer, she followed up with a lower offer, aiming to secure the fruit at a price that maximizes her own benefit. This pattern of incremental concessions is a common tactic in bargaining situations, as it allows negotiators to test the other party's resolve while gradually moving towards a mutually acceptable agreement.





          Options available to Cedric Meadowbrook: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of three and a half coins or reject it.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer is 6, because he would be losing half a coin compared to what he initially agreed upon, and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 8, because he risks losing the entire sale and having to find another buyer.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins for the lot, and that's my final offer.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins for the lot, and that's my final offer.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Excuse me, miss, but I'm sure someone else would be happy to take these off my hands at a fair price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, now, Mr. Figtree, surely we can come to an agreement that benefits us both. These fruits look lovely, but six coins is a bit steep for my budget.
      Della Plumstone -- "How about four coins for the whole lot? That's a fair price, wouldn't you say?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, four coins it is.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins, and they're the finest fruit in Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Mr. Meadowbrook. That's a fair price for these fine fruits.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, four coins it is.
      Della Plumstone -- "These fruits look lovely, Mr. Meadowbrook, but I'm sure we can find a price that suits us both. Perhaps three coins and a half?


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins for the lot, and that's my final offer.
